It depends on what you mean by “see.” With our naked eyes, the best you can do under the best conditions is a nearby galaxy, which for most people on a clear dark night is the Andromeda Galaxy at about 2.5 million light years. Telescopes, of course, greatly extend the distances we can see, with the best observations detecting the earliest bright objects a few hundred million years after the beginning of the universe, at something like 13.5 billion years ago (which in terms of actual distance now has more than tripled due to the ongoing expansion of the universe, as the intervening distances get stretched out). The light from these distant objects is also being stretched out so that what was visible light then is in the infrared, and what we would now detect as visible light was originally in the ultraviolet. But if “seeing” means detecting any wavelength of electromagnetic radiation, then the furthest we can see is the cosmic microwave background radiation that originated about 380,000 years after the beginning, when the universe had cooled down to the point that neutral atoms of hydrogen and helium could form (which is when photons could then propagate unimpeded, and the opaque universe became transparent). Beyond that, we cannot “see” anything unless we make use of phenomena such as gravity waves, which can give us hints as to what was going on in the first seconds of the universe’s existence.

We can reach as far back as the MWBG radiation 380,000 years after the Big bang. But we cannot go much further than at the verge of the solar system for now. Furthermore there’s something curious about traveling in the universe. Let’s say that you go to the moon. Before going, when you look at the moon, you’re not looking in “space” you’re looking in “time”. The farther you look, the older is what you see. So when you travel towards the Moon you’re really traveling through time.
If you travel at the speed of light it would take 144 k years just to leave the milkyway.
